Award.AwardTitle: LSCBR - The Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center at the Ohio State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
A National Science Foundation award has been made to The Ohio State University, under the direction of Erich Grotewold, to support the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC, http://abrc.osu.edu). The ABRC was established in 1991 with the mission to collect, preserve, propagate and distribute diverse resources of Arabidopsis thaliana and related species. With continuing support from the NSF, the resources have expanded to include seed, DNA, protein and cell culture stocks as well as educational materials, resulting in the current collection of almost one million stocks. The ABRC serves a very large and dynamic community of over 20,000 plant researchers worldwide with a common goal to understand the basic processes of flowering plants, as well as to apply this understanding to further crop improvement.

The activities of the Center are essential to support collective efforts of the community to functionally characterize the Arabidopsis genome and genes. This is reflected in increasing number of orders, which have reached almost 100,000 stocks annually. The Center continues to expand the existing collections and to identify potential interest for new stocks, driven by community needs. Realizing the strategic position of the ABRC in the Arabidopsis and plant community, the Center started several educational activities (K-12 and College-level) to increase the appreciation for Arabidopsis and plants in general in the younger generations, activities that will be continued and expanded during the next five years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 1991, the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) has provided an essential service to the scientific community by collecting, preserving, propagating and distributing diverse resources of Arabidopsis thaliana and related species. Central to the mission of the ABRC is to secure seed and DNA stocks for the next decades. With almost one million stocks, 30,000 users, and 200,000 samples distributed each year, ABRC represents one of the largest repositories for researchers and educators worldwide.

This funding enabled the Center to continue serving and anticipating the needs of the community as they have developed. The funding period was highlighted by a substantial increase in the efficiency of the operation, releasing more time and resources to perform quality control and improve the quality of service and stocks. In this period, the Center has acquired a custom-made robotic seed dispensing system, which has been instrumental in generating new large sets of mutant lines, covering the majority of Arabidopsis genome.  A number of large collections of DNA stocks, along with a number of novel types of resources have been obtained, including cell cultures, protein chips, education kits, and antibodies.  A coordinated community effort of studying natural variation within the “1001 Genomes” project has resulted in a simultaneous release of the sequence data for about 1,400 natural accessions of Arabidopsis thaliana and corresponding stocks. ABRC has embraced the CRISPR/Cas9 resources and is developing a database infrastructure to fully support these. Capitalizing on the capacity and expertise of the Center, housing and distribution services have been offered for high-throughput resources, such as large clone collections of different species. ABRC education efforts have been focused on both K-12 and college-level education, and resulted in the development of 20 education modules. With over 2,000 education stocks distributed annually to 23 countries worldwide, ABRC is nowhere close to saturating the needs of the teaching community. With the advancement of the curricula that place an emphasis on the importance of hands-on teaching and independent research projects, the collection of one million Arabidopsis stocks offers an unprecedented tool for mining teaching resources and ideas.

 


Last Modified: 04/01/2016
Modified by: Jelena Brkljacic

The funding period was highlighted by a substantial increase in the efficiency of the operation, releasing more time and resources to perform quality control and improve the quality of service and stocks. In this period, the Center has acquired a custom-made robotic seed dispensing system, which has been instrumental in generating new large sets of mutant lines, covering the majority of Arabidopsis genome. A number of large collections of DNA stocks, along with a number of novel types of resources have been obtained, including cell cultures, protein chips, education kits, and antibodies. A coordinated community effort of studying natural variation within the "1001 Genomes" project has resulted in a simultaneous release of the sequence data for about 1,400 natural accessions of Arabidopsis thaliana and corresponding stocks. ABRC has embraced the CRISPR/Cas9 resources and is developing a database infrastructure to fully support these. With the advancement of the curricula that place an emphasis on the importance of hands-on teaching and independent research projects, the collection of one million Arabidopsis stocks offers an unprecedented tool for mining teaching resources and ideas.
